liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Rugby union's national governing body has joined the NRL and the Australian Olympic Committee in formally supporting the proposed Indigenous Voice to Parliament. Rugby Australia chairman Hamish McLennan told ABC Radio Sydney the code has a very long and proud association with Indigenous players, and the decision taken by the Rugby Australia board was a natural fit. The AFL is expected to make its own decision shortly. Rugby Australia announced its decision this morning in a full-page newspaper advertisement, arguing that the referendum on the Voice is "too important a contest to watch in silence" .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Rugby Australia backs Voice to Parliament

props.alt: A middle-aged white man in a suit sits in front of two rugby uniforms.

children.content: Rugby Australia chairman Hamish McLennan
(ABC News)
Rugby union's national governing body has joined the NRL and the Australian Olympic Committee in formally supporting the proposed
Indigenous Voice to Parliament
Rugby Australia chairman
Hamish McLennan
told ABC Radio Sydney the code has a very long and proud association with Indigenous players, and the decision taken by the Rugby Australia board was a natural fit.
The AFL is expected to make its own decision shortly.
Rugby Australia announced its decision this morning in a full-page newspaper advertisement, arguing that the referendum on the Voice is
"too important a contest to watch in silence"

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Disgraced Theranos Chief Executive Elizabeth Holmes will begin an 11-year prison sentence on May 30 after she lost her bid to remain free. Holmes is facing prison time for defrauding investors in a blood-testing scam. US District Judge Edward Davila set Holmes' revised prison-reporting date after her lawyers proposed it in a filing on Wednesday. It came after a federal appeals court rejected Holmes' bid to remain out of prison while she attempts to overturn her conviction on four felony counts of fraud and conspiracy. The punishment also includes a $452 million restitution bill that Mr Davila ordered Holmes to pay in a separate ruling issued late on Tuesday.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Elizabeth Holmes to start prison sentence at end of month

children.content: Disgraced Theranos Chief Executive Elizabeth Holmes will begin an 11-year prison sentence on May 30 after she lost her bid to remain free.
Holmes is facing prison time for defrauding investors in a blood-testing scam.

props.alt: Elizabeth Holmes walks down a street.

children.content: (AP: Jeff Chiu)
US District Judge Edward Davila set Holmes' revised prison-reporting date after her lawyers proposed it in a filing on Wednesday.
It came after a federal appeals court rejected Holmes' bid to remain out of prison while she attempts to overturn her conviction on four felony counts of fraud and conspiracy.
The punishment also includes a $452 million restitution bill that Mr Davila ordered Holmes to pay in a separate ruling issued late on Tuesday.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The ACT's director of public prosecutions (DPP), Shane Drumgold, has been stood aside from the position while the board of inquiry into the handling of the Bruce Lehrmann case continues. His deputy, Anthony Williamson SC, will act in the position until June 13. Mr Drumgold has been under pressure in questioning at the board of inquiry, which is examining how the criminal case against Mr Lehrman, for the alleged rape of Brittany Higgins at Parliament House, was handled by criminal justice agencies. Mr Lehrmann has maintained his innocence and there have been no findings against him after the criminal trial was abandoned.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ACT director of public prosecutions stood aside as Lehrmann trial inquiry continues

Mr Lehrmann has maintained his innocence and there have been no findings against him after the criminal trial was abandoned.

items.synopsis: Wall Street has bounced upwards as US president Joe Biden reassures his citizens that "America will not default". Australian shares are set to follow the US markets. Follow the day's financial news and insights from our specialist business reporters on our live blog.

title.children: Joe Biden reassurres that 'America will not default', pushing up US stocks and ASX futures

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Good morning! While you were sleeping, there was a bounce of optimism in the United States, as its citizens were reassured by their president that "America will not default". "I’m confident that we'll get the agreement on the budget," Joe Biden added. The United States is facing the prospect of defaulting on trillions of dollars worth of loans, unless the Republicans and Democrats strike a deal to legally allow the US Department of Treasury to incur more debt, which would allow it to pay its bills. US Treasury officials say that, unless a deal is reached, the US risks running out of money to pay its debts as soon as June 1, and this could trigger a recession, sparking fears of a global economic and financial crisis. But those comments by Biden have seemed to soothe equity markets there, at least, for now. And of course, Australian shares are set to follow. Meanwhile, the US dollar rose overnight, pushing the Australian currency against the greenback slightly down to 66.62 US cents. Let's hope those sixes aren't ominous. Here in Australia, we have labour force data out at 11:30am AEST. Will Australia’s unemployment remain steady at near a 50 year low of 3.5 per cent, or will we start to get an uptick as interest rates crimp demand? We'll be here keeping you updated.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: US equities up as Biden reassures that 'America will not default'

featuredLink.title: 'It's a really huge deal': Why the US debt ceiling crisis has implications for Australia

children.content: Good morning!
While you were sleeping, there was a bounce of optimism in the United States, as its citizens were reassured by their president that "America will not default".
"I’m confident that we'll get the agreement on the budget," Joe Biden added.

The United States is facing the prospect of defaulting on trillions of dollars worth of loans, unless the Republicans and Democrats strike a deal to legally allow the US Department of Treasury to incur more debt, which
would allow it to pay its bills.
US Treasury officials say that, unless a deal is reached, the US risks running out of money to pay its debts as soon as June 1, and this
could trigger a recession, sparking fears of a global economic and financial crisis.
But those comments by Biden have seemed to soothe equity markets there, at least, for now.
And of course, Australian shares are set to follow.
Meanwhile, the US dollar rose overnight, pushing the Australian currency against the greenback slightly down to 66.62 US cents. Let's hope those sixes aren't ominous.

Here in Australia, we have labour force data out at 11:30am AEST. Will Australia’s unemployment remain steady at near a 50 year low of 3.5 per cent, or will we start to get an uptick as interest rates crimp demand?
We'll be here keeping you updated.
